page.title: 05BRAYDON TRANSPORT
page.content: The most striking aspect is the almost total lack of public transport. One would not expect to find a railway station in such a spot, but buses, run by the local authorities, rarely call in this outlying area. Bus stops for some housesholds are two miles away, an impossible journey for mothers with young children, and not pleasant for anyone on a cold, wet day. The elderly residents tend to rely on families and neighbours for shopping as they cannot usually afford to run a car. Others have to rely totally on their own private transport usually a car or, popular with farmers, a Land Rover. Bread and grocery deliveries are made by a van converted into a mobile shop. This service, though, is in jeopardy.
